lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can listen to a story and identify key characters, locations, and foods mentioned.
supportStrategies: (Listening) Before playing the story, ask: “What foods do you think they’ll talk about?” Students check predictions while listening.
stretchStrategies: Students change the end of the story by adding a fridge full of food. They act out what the characters eat or cook, using the unit’s target sentences.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can read the story aloud, act it out, and answer questions using the target language.
supportStrategies: (Speaking) Read the story aloud. Assign roles. Students read, then act out using food props or gestures. Finish with simple comprehension Qs.
stretchStrategies: Students change the end of the story by adding a fridge full of food. They act out what the characters eat or cook, using the unit’s target sentences.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can create a simple, imaginative ending to the story by drawing or performing it.
supportStrategies: (4Cs – Creativity) Pause before the story ends. Ask: “What could be in their fridge?” or “What will they cook?” Students draw or explain in pairs.
stretchStrategies: Students change the end of the story by adding a fridge full of food. They act out what the characters eat or cook, using the unit’s target sentences.

items: Food in syllabi typically Western-centric: banh mi >> bread
Hai con chó >> two dog [two dogs]. Not only the form, but the pronunciation is tough here, as it changes depending on the final sound of the noun [s,z,iz]

Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
